content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												My friend bought me this game and I have never sat down and tried to play it seriously, so I am only writing this at his request. I don't really get it.I say that with a lot of games. And usually it's because I don't have the patience and like to blame other things for my own faults. I've only played it multiplayer, and it felt like there was no real strategy. My friends and I would all pick whatever characters ( I was the Mole because he was by far the coolest ) and would pretty much just run about the stage doing whatever. We were probably only on the default difficulty, and obviously weren't going for any high scores, yet nothing was really stopping us. We would waltz right into the building or whatever, grab the money, knock a few people out, die, get revived, and then eventually progress through the level and win. I never felt like I was supposedly to play differently. It almost felt like I didn't even need to, because if I could play sloppy like this, why waste my time trying to be smart and stealthy?I'm a bit biased against the game, because I feel like I never really gave it a chance. I think if you have the patience to try and play it strategically then it could be interesting. I do think it's a relatively original concept, so it has that going for it. Plus, everyone speaks French so that's kinda cool.Pretty colours / 10.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												With a colorful artstyle and a chaotic nature, this is a game where you seem not to know what is going on at any moment in time. Yes, I am here reviewing yet another four-person co-opertative. This is a very strange type of game through concept, but achieves enjoyment through being very chaotic, escpcially when all four players are present for the experience. There are multiple characters to play as, with each one having a special ability that assist the team in one way or another. You can play through the game either through the stealth means or running through it, getting spotted by the security will peforming said action. This video game was specifcally taliored for co-opertative, as having multiple individuals in the game at once is benefital to the success of the operation. If you are trying to play this without being spotted, it is very difficult, with their being a mass amount of security officer and civilans present on each level. There are ways to avoid said obstacles, such as vents and other means of traveling around. The gameplay is enjoyable, with teamwork infused into multiple actions, such as if a teammate was killed you will need to go to revive them and can not proceed without doing so. So, would I recommend Monaco, yes, as it is an enjoyable co-operative experience.

Posted: October 20, 2014
												Monaco is a hidden gem. At first glance, when watching youtube videos of it, it looks complicated and probably boring, but I couldn't be more wrong. Monaco is one of my favorite game. It is a top down view, and there are different class, and you basically try to steal treasures while avoiding guards, camera, civilians, lasers, etc.; sounds boring? but trust me, it is really fun. It's a shame that there are almost no one playing online. Don't let that discourage you though, single player is really fun, but better with multiplayer. Like I said, this game is a hidden gem.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												I wasn't sure what to expect from Monaco, whether it would be more arcade or more realistic. And I've come to the conclusion it's a little bit of both.When you open the game, the menu itself moves very nicely, with graphics flowing in the background. Right off the bat, there are multiple gamemode options. I dove right into “Campaign” mode, and, like many other games, it showed me the first mission I could complete in color, and all the others were grayed out. However, what I really liked about playing Monaco's campaign, is that I could join/start a lobby, have up to three other people with me, and could stay in that lobby and keep selecting episodes instead of having to join a new lobby for each episode. The gameplay itself is very nice. You start on the first episode by choosing one of four characters, each with their own perk. As you progress through levels, you gain more characters. The game loads very quickly, after you depart from the neat lobby menu of changing options (which is always fun). It is a top-down game, but there are obviously good reasons for that. On the top, directions will be given as to what you have to do, so that it's never confusing, and the goal is to sneak past the police/guards to get to the object the heist was started for and all the spare money along the way. There are weapons to pick up from time to time, but I found that running away from guards and hiding in a room for a few seconds keeps them off your scent.Pros:Menus move very smoothly.The graphics, being a top-down game, are pretty decent.The objectives are always clear.You can stay in the same lobby for as many levels as you choose.All campaign levels can be completed in either singleplayer or multiplayer.The controller support is amazing, and I actually prefer to use the controller.There's Steam Workshop to download new levels to play.It's local co-op too, so it's good for a party with friends if you have more than one controller.Cons:Gun reloading is very obnoxious. It shouldn't take 10 seconds for one bullet to reload.The co-op community is not as large as I had hoped.Guards are almost too easy to get past.So, basically, I had a lot of fun playing this game, though I would recommend getting it on sale.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												If you're into 8-bit games, and into intense strategy, then this is a must-buy.Atmosphere:The background music is great, gives a nice touch while playing.Gameplay: Alot a variety with 8 "classes" with each with his/her own specialization. Multiplayer is where this really starts to shine.Graphics:It's a 8-bit game, why bother?Story:If you're willing to read every dialog, then the story itslef is pretty good.Downsides:Controls and gameplay styles are easy to play, but hard to master.Overall: I'd give it a 9/10, one of the best games of it's type out there.

Posted: September 8, 2014
												If you want a nice over-the-top stealth game that has a lot of variety and challenge, then Monaco will satisfy your desire. The stealth mechanics are well implemented and the different Thieves all have different playstyles and abilities. The stock story is really fun and even more when playing with friends. You can get a solid 30 hours out of the stock story without going for all trophies. After the regular story, you can play in zombie mode, where stealth isn't as big of a factor as on-the-fly decision making. Whether you are playing alone or with friends, I would recommend this game to you.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												Monaco Whats Yours Is Mine     We've all had that fantasy, you know, the one where you plan an elaborate heist, Even if you haven't i'm sure you have at least seen ocean's 11. Sadly if you tried this in real life you would risk going to prison, but fret no more because finally a game has come out where you can do just that (other than payday), without suffering the real life consequences of robbing a bank.     Sound 4/5     Art 5/5     Gameplay 4/5     Story 3/5     Overall 16/20     On the sound spectrum i think I was rather generous as the music is not tremendous (purely my opinion), but there are no horrible sound effects that take away from the experience of the game. Where it really excels in this spectrum is the voice acting. while not much dialogue, the little there is is very funny.      At the quality AAA games are at in this day of age it is hard for small teams to get that same feel, so many go for the retro look. However, just because the graphics aren't of their era doesn't write them off the art category. Even though it may not look real it is still one of most beautifully presented games i have ever seen. they really pushed what they could do with the graphics they had     The gameplay is light, fun and a blast with friends. the high speed robbery is a great mechanic and can only be built on,and with so many different classes to choose from it can take a lot of planning until you and your friends have the perfect bank mugging dream team. you can also go solo if you wish and will still be challenged to a very fun and strategic game. Sometimes you can spend hours trying to get that top spot on the leaderboards and it is a game that suites that competitiveness completely. sadly, this game can get slightly repetitave after playing for a while and the replay value isnt great at this point     The story in this game is good but not great, it is quite simple and engaging but gets quite predictable and you sometimes just skip some dialogues before the level completely. However, the story gets the job done and really is not what this game is focused on. like many retro style games story is an afterthought and that definately shows in Monaco, but it is not bad to a point that it ruins the game     I would recommend this game to anyone who has any taste in games. with all the cookie-cutter fps games there are it is pleasant to see something  innovative and new. It is well worth the money and I think most people would have a good time with it

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Monaco takes the style of the classic pacman gameplay where you collect loot in a top down view and makes it 10 times more fun, involved, and frantic, wither you're playing alone, or with friends.The goal of each level is to go through a series of "floors" of a location and collect all the trophies, then escape. However, this is quite easily done, and most if not all players will eventually decide to start clearing floors, which involves you collecting all the coins on each floor, as well as the trophies, before moving onto the next. Clearing a whole level is a fun challenge that rewards you with a harder version of that level.The game plays quite differently on Singleplayer than it does on Multiplayer most of the time. If you're someone who loves stealth and likes to take it slowly and perfectly, then singleplayer is for you, where some obsticles will require a small plan if you want to get past it unnoticed. Multiplayer is more fast paced, with almost always something going wrong.  You'll quickly find 4 players running around the level hiding in bushes and reviving each other while being chased by dogs, helicopters, guards and more - it's a great laugh.The game has a whole bunch of content to keep you going for hours - just look at my playtime - 100 hours (almost!). There's 3 campaigns, each of which can be played on a normal mode, and a zombie mode where even civillians try to kill you, then there's custom levels, which are made by you and other players alike. Custom levels means there's a level editor which will also keep you busy if that's your thing - its loads of fun to design a place to rob, believe me!All in all, Monaco is a great game to pick up and play for an hour or two whenever you want. When you start out give it a few hours so you can get used to the art style, which can confuse a lot of people at first, and make sure you play more than the first few levels - they're mainly just tutorial levels!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												6 hours in and I can already tell that this game was a good use of my money.Right from the get-go, I liked it. I have a soft spot for good stealth games, and this game set off on the right foot by following my 3 basic rules for making a decent stealth game:1. The player must always be aware hgow close they are to being spotted by each guard2. There must be many ways to approach one goal in an open-ended level3. The controls must be tight and responsive enough for the player to have agency in the gameplayMonaco does all three things very well: each guard has a sight meter over them which fills up over time, the levels are open-ended and full of extra ways to navigate them, and the player is simple and fun to control.A good buy, even when not on sale. When it does go on sale, but four copies and have fun remaking the heist movie of your choice!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Solid multiplayer game. This game has both local co-op and online, though not both at the same time.   It's a fun game that can both be played as a strategic heist game, or a fun run through a guard infested building.   It works well as a multiplayer, or single player, and can be enjoyed equally in either mode. Personally I find it best in couch co-op though it can be frustrating.  Some of the mechanics are a little annoying. (sight doesn't work as you expect at times), and a few rooms feel like you need certain abilities to "cleanly" get away. But where else are you going to get a mole to dig a tunnel through a wall, to allow a hacker to hack a light switch to disable a security laser, then let the lock smith unlock a safe, while the lookout is watching for guards.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												My only complaint about the game is that the classes are boring. Currently the classes you can play as are: a “locksmith,” a “pickpocket,” a “cleaner,” a “lookout,” a “mole,” a “gentleman,” a “hacker,” a “redhead,” and a “blonde.” Really? No WONDER so few finished the game. The people we played with are just boring. Cliches. Veritable “mehs.”But it doesn’t have to stay this way. Pocketwatch Games can fix this by replacing these classes with cooler ones. Specifically these:We can replace the “locksmith” with “Sasha Grey.” The Sasha Grey class makes money by taking many hard tasks simultaneously (often four at a time!). She takes them harder and faster than the other classes and, though they would cause other classes such vertigo that others would vomit, she, at her limits, would just gag and roll her eyes back and ask for more, and with profanities! This class is like a “tank,” and can take great punishment.As for the “pickpocket,” how about “Jenna Haze”? Jenna Haze has an easy-going, perky personality. She’s the charmer of the group. She’s enthusiastic and energetic, bending over to do almost any task. She also has tan skin. This is useful.As for “the cleaner,” that can be replaced by “Tori Black.” Not particularly good at anything but above average at everything, you can count on her to do basically anything. And I mean anything. Some of the others may resent her non-specialization—but the absolute value of her skills makes her a force to be watched.The “lookout”? Let’s replace ‘im with “Lexi Belle.” Don’t let her quiet, high school girl demeanor make you think she’s not willing to do dirty deeds. She’s the innocent-looking one among this group, and you’re going to need her, because, well, everyone else in the group looks a little…suspicious? I think that’s the word. You’re going to need Lexi Belle to balance that look out.And the “mole.” How about “Jesse Jane”? Having grown up on military bases, this girl has the discipline and experience necessary to get almost any job done (wink wink). She’s a down-to-earth girl; not as sunshine and unicorns as Jenna, but not as hard as Sasha. And she has a mischievous facial expression none of the others have. You really want this girl on the team.What of the “gentleman”? Well, obviously: James Deen. With his boyish face, athletic physique, and blue eyes, he’s obviously a gentleman. Female guards will look at him and immediately become disarmed (of COURSE there are female guards in this game! Don’t be a sexist!). He has an incredible amount of experience for his age, and unlike many of the other male candidates for the job, well, he can play the “gentleman.” He’s also a good team player; he can work with the rest of the group all night long, and in many positions.Speaking of which, let’s replace the “hacker” with “Stoya.” Graduating high school at age 16, and being versed in computers and games (plus being a writer), how could we NOT want her on the team? She’s the nerd, and the most rebellious of the group; the proper answer to “the hacker.” Being of Scottish and Serbian ethnicity, she also brings something exotic to the team. How many Scottish, Serbian Americans have you played with?Now, the “redhead.” Coming out of retirement, we have “Faye Reagan.” Retiring from “the industry” early due to drug problems, Faye in this game gets a second chance at life. She realizes that she just has to focus on being good at what she believes in, which is sharing the wealth that her mind and body are capable of with this team of stars.And as for the “blonde,” “Kayden Kross.” No longer a performer but rather a director, she will be the leader of our group. This Swedish American writes well (though not as well as Stoya) and, with her French husband and partner in crime Manuel Ferrara, we can expect her to sweep Monaco’s rich men. Or perhaps rich women? (Mr. Ferrera demands that she work only with women for some reason if she DOES have to perform) (we’ll have to keep her away from the James Deen I guess). Kayden also happens to be the most beautiful of the group. Beautiful in that she has an aura of leadership.And there you have it! Just imagine all these characters in some Monaco mansion, working together all at once! Oh what fun that would be! Pocketwatch games! Give us what we desire!

												Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine Review - Raymond KTSuffers from the same problem Dungeon Defenders did, in that it provides cooperative play without an incentive to utilize it (indeed in both cases it was almost a hindrance to bring others into the game). Had some fun with it though, probably worth checking out if you're not expecting much and you're just looking for a casual experience to share with a few people. I'd recommend waiting for a sale though. I wished there were more people playing this game. Multiplayer is pretty dead, need some AI bots to revive it.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I love the fact that I can go all Jihad and suicide bomb the guards in this game. That's probably my favorite part.This game is one of if not my favorite game I've played. It is hilarious.There is much entertainment value in it, you can play with friends, you can build your own maps, and the replay value is phenomenal.They have two separate campaigns (I guess it's sort of like the same campaign only the level gets bigger and more difficult). The different characters you can play are very diverse (not the bad, politically correct way) and have different skills. The NPCs are friggin' HILARIOUS in their interactions with you and the bush in which you are hiding (but they, of course KNOW you could not possibly be hiding there) and it's just an all around well balanced and fun as hell game.I give this game an 11/10 (because that's possible).

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Monaco is a unique take on the Heist genre and I applaud it. Story-There are a total of 49 story missions divided into 4 campaigns - Locksmith's Story(17 missions), Pickpocket's Story(16 missions), Origins(8 missions), Fin(8 missions). You can choose to do these missions in 3 different modes: Enhanced, Classic, Zombie. The Enhanced and Classic levels are practically the same except that some layout and AI changes have been made to the levels in Enhanced mode to make them easier.-The general story follows a group of thieves(The Locksmith, The Lookout, The Cleaner and The Pickpocket) as they finish various jobs for money or other things. As the story progresses, new members join the group, The Gentleman, The Hacker, The Mole, and the Redhead. The actual story is told by two members of the original cast - The Locksmith and the Pickpocket. They both share their versions of what they've done to an inspector. Those stories are very different in difficulty and actual narration.Locksmith's Story-Narrated mostly by the Locksmith. The "Easy" mode of this game if you ask me, and  the levels are similiar to the Pickpocket's story.Pickpocket's Story-Mostly narrated by the Pickpocket. The "Hard" versions of the missions from the Locksmith's story. Levels are fairly similiar but there are still some major differences. It includes one of the greatest twists that I have ever seen. SPOILER ALERT:The first crew(Locksmith,Lookout,Pickpocket,Cleaner) are the same people as the the second crew(Gentleman,Mole,Hacker,Redhead). The original crew was made up by the Gentleman to avoid arrest.Origins- Narrated by the Lookout talking to an Inspector.  Explains why the thieves started doing what they're doing. For them, the law doesn't apply until a "moral debt" is repaid to them. The Lookout, for example, does this because Haitian soldiers stole all her family's possessions.Fin-The Finale.Narrated by two inspectors chasing the thieves. The missions are mostly cleaning up evidence from previous jobs and escaping police officers that are looking for you.Gameplay-The gameplay mostly focuses on stealth - going in guns blazing is still possible but not recommended. Unlike other top down view games, this game doesn't allow you to see around corners unless your character leaves cover. The game instead gives you a blueprint of parts of the map you've already been to but you can't see where guards, civilians, and other useful items are.You are allowed to sneak and that will greatly reduce the distance from which guards and civilians spot you. Controls are very simple and most of the interactions require you to just walk into something and hold the same button until it's done. At the beginning of each level, you are presented with backpacks that hold various items. The backpacks can hold shotguns, SMGs, smoke grenades, C4, EMP, Wrenches that complete any action instantly, and even a rocket launcher and many more. This equipment is not mandatory to complete the mission, but highly recommended. Collecting 10 coins grants one more "ammo". A somewhat unrealistic mechanic is in the game - you can hide in bushes to hide from guards, though you if you are spotted while entering it or they will attack you. Some enemies are overpowered, like the Shotgun SWAT and the RPG Soldiers but they only appear on maps where they are generally easy to avoid. It's possible to beat this game in singleplayer, but co-op with a mic is highly recommended. Local co-op is also available, so that's a huge plus. Planning how to enter a building and how to disable an annoying laser to get the trophy with a friend feels amazing.The game, if you haven't noticed, also has a workshop. Sadly, we are not allowed to create weapons or character skins or props(you can, however, modify these in the game files) but in exchange we can create maps. Oh yes, your custom heist. It's really easy to learn how to use the ingame editor so you'll find yourself making a complex mission after 5 minutes of practice.Characters-The thieves in Monaco all have different special abilites, and that is, in my opinion, the greatest strength of the game. Though some are more powerful than others, each character has its usefulness.-Original Crew-The Locksmith: Can open locked doors, safes, ATMs and cash registers faster than any class-The Lookout: While sneaking, special icons represent enemies and civilians on the blueprint part of the map, allowing players to sense danger before it appears.-The Cleaner: Can knock guards and civilians unconscious and they remain in that state for a short period of time(~30 seconds).-The Pickpocket: His pet monkey follows him around and collects any coins that he misses.-New Members-The Gentleman: Can disguise himself while hidden allowing him to traverse areas that are normally off limits. Needs to stay away from guards and civilians or his cover will be blown almost instantly. (My favourite character.)-The Hacker: Can insert viruses into power outlets(crazy, right?) which allows him to disable security.-The Mole: Can dig through walls allowing you to get behind enemy lines.-The Redhead: Going near one guard,civilian(even female), or even a dog charms them and causes them to follow you around, allowing your team to get around easier.Special:-Blonde: The Redhead but when she was younger. Guards only attack when they get close. Only available in Redhead's origin mission and custom missions.Final VerdictStory: 9/10 - Considering that it's not the main focus of the game(and it shouldn't be), it's surprisingly good including the twist at the end.Gameplay: 10/10 - Read the Gameplay segment.Characters: 10/10 - The game doesn't give little information, but at the same time doesn't overload us. The perfect middle.Overall:10/10

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is a hell of a lot of fun.  Stealth games are something you dont see pulled off to well too often and this game really does a good job of creating tension while hiding and panic when you've been spotted.  When there are more than a few players in the game it becomes pure chaos, someone screws up and gets spotted and then theres a chain reaction where everyone gets dragged into it and are all scrambling to find a hiding spot.  The game has VOIP built in so if you play this with your friends you will all be screaming at each other while playing, its great.  There still seems to be a player base so you can play online with people but I reccomend getting a premade group together to go through it as some of the other players might already know what to do and take a lot of the challenge away.  This game has a bunch of different difficulty modes some of which i've not gone through yet because they were added after the last time I played but I will be trying to move through them now.  The game does get quite challenging so depending on your penchant for punishment you may only end up doing one of the story runs.  There are also community made maps and some quirky player vs player maps that add more content to the game. I find the art style and story to suit the gameplay quite well and really enjoy the charactes and how there are different campaigns that tell different sides of the story from different perspectives. All in all very quality experience for 15 dollars, highly reccomend.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												This is a very unique and awesome stealth game. It has a strong emphasis on co-operative multiplayer gameplay, which more and more games are tapping into, and for the better.As a single-player title, it is not particularly impressive. It has its moments, but for a long while, the game is just too easy. Luckily, it has a lot of challenging and fun levels later on in which you'll actually have to play it stealthy.As a multiplayer game, it is one of the best gaming experiences one can have. I think having 2 players instead of 3 or 4 is still best, but all options are very fun. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a game to play with friends, and also any fans of the stealth genre (like me!).

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Monaco has one of the most unique gameplay combinations I have played, its filled with indie pixely goodness, but also has a detailed "stealth" system along with 4 player co-op and a level editor makes for near endless fun. Monaco doesn't let its art style hold it back from telling a story either, throughout the campaign you will learn about the characters and what motivates them. The protagonists are each there own character with there own "personality", something I would think hard to do given the graphical style of the game. I think you should give Monaco a try. Its not an expensive game but it is definitely worth a few bucks!

The actual story is told by two members of the original cast - The Locksmith and the Pickpocket. They both share their versions of what they've done to an inspector. Those stories are very different in difficulty and actual narration.Locksmith's Story-Narrated mostly by the Locksmith. The "Easy" mode of this game if you ask me, and  the levels are similiar to the Pickpocket's story.Pickpocket's Story-Mostly narrated by the Pickpocket. The "Hard" versions of the missions from the Locksmith's story. Levels are fairly similiar but there are still some major differences. It includes one of the greatest twists that I have ever seen. SPOILER ALERT:The first crew(Locksmith,Lookout,Pickpocket,Cleaner) are the same people as the the second crew(Gentleman,Mole,Hacker,Redhead). The original crew was made up by the Gentleman to avoid arrest.Origins- Narrated by the Lookout talking to an Inspector.  Explains why the thieves started doing what they're doing. For them, the law doesn't apply until a "moral debt" is repaid to them. The Lookout, for example, does this because Haitian soldiers stole all her family's possessions.Fin-The Finale.Narrated by two inspectors chasing the thieves. The missions are mostly cleaning up evidence from previous jobs and escaping police officers that are looking for you.Gameplay-The gameplay mostly focuses on stealth - going in guns blazing is still possible but not recommended. Unlike other top down view games, this game doesn't allow you to see around corners unless your character leaves cover. The game instead gives you a blueprint of parts of the map you've already been to but you can't see where guards, civilians, and other useful items are.You are allowed to sneak and that will greatly reduce the distance from which guards and civilians spot you. Controls are very simple and most of the interactions require you to just walk into something and hold the same button until it's done. At the beginning of each level, you are presented with backpacks that hold various items. The backpacks can hold shotguns, SMGs, smoke grenades, C4, EMP, Wrenches that complete any action instantly, and even a rocket launcher and many more. This equipment is not mandatory to complete the mission, but highly recommended. Collecting 10 coins grants one more "ammo". A somewhat unrealistic mechanic is in the game - you can hide in bushes to hide from guards, though you if you are spotted while entering it or they will attack you. Some enemies are overpowered, like the Shotgun SWAT and the RPG Soldiers but they only appear on maps where they are generally easy to avoid. It's possible to beat this game in singleplayer, but co-op with a mic is highly recommended. Local co-op is also available, so that's a huge plus. Planning how to enter a building and how to disable an annoying laser to get the trophy with a friend feels amazing.The game, if you haven't noticed, also has a workshop. Sadly, we are not allowed to create weapons or character skins or props(you can, however, modify these in the game files) but in exchange we can create maps. Oh yes, your custom heist. It's really easy to learn how to use the ingame editor so you'll find yourself making a complex mission after 5 minutes of practice.Characters-The thieves in Monaco all have different special abilites, and that is, in my opinion, the greatest strength of the game. Though some are more powerful than others, each character has its usefulness.-Original Crew-The Locksmith: Can open locked doors, safes, ATMs and cash registers faster than any class-The Lookout: While sneaking, special icons represent enemies and civilians on the blueprint part of the map, allowing players to sense danger before it appears.-The Cleaner: Can knock guards and civilians unconscious and they remain in that state for a short period of time(~30 seconds).-The Pickpocket: His pet monkey follows him around and collects any coins that he misses.-New Members-The Gentleman: Can disguise himself while hidden allowing him to traverse areas that are normally off limits. Needs to stay away from guards and civilians or his cover will be blown almost instantly. (My favourite character.)-The Hacker: Can insert viruses into power outlets(crazy, right?) which allows him to disable security.-The Mole: Can dig through walls allowing you to get behind enemy lines.-The Redhead: Going near one guard,civilian(even female), or even a dog charms them and causes them to follow you around, allowing your team to get around easier.Special:-Blonde: The Redhead but when she was younger. Guards only attack when they get close. Only available in Redhead's origin mission and custom missions.Final VerdictStory: 9/10 - Considering that it's not the main focus of the game(and it shouldn't be), it's surprisingly good including the twist at the end.Gameplay: 10/10 - Read the Gameplay segment.Characters: 10/10 - The game doesn't give little information, but at the same time doesn't overload us. The perfect middle.Overall:10/10

												I love the fact that I can go all Jihad and suicide bomb the guards in this game. That's probably my favorite part.This game is one of if not my favorite game I've played. It is hilarious.There is much entertainment value in it, you can play with friends, you can build your own maps, and the replay value is phenomenal.They have two separate campaigns (I guess it's sort of like the same campaign only the level gets bigger and more difficult). The different characters you can play are very diverse (not the bad, politically correct way) and have different skills. The NPCs are friggin' HILARIOUS in their interactions with you and the bush in which you are hiding (but they, of course KNOW you could not possibly be hiding there) and it's just an all around well balanced and fun as hell game.I give this game an 11/10 (because that's possible).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Having put 60 hours into this game solo and co-op with an additional 25 hours in creating my own custom mission, I felt it's finally time to leave a quick review. This is a great game for casual gamers like myself. With my short attention span for games nowadays, it's awesome to come across one that is so simple in concept that it is easy to pick up. Missions range from a few minutes to maybe 45 minutes, and it's just perfect.Even when you're done with the campaigns, there is a plethora of custom missions created by dedicated players. Of course, not all are winners, but there are definitely some very fun ones to play with friends.And of course, that brings me to the best aspect of this game: Co-op play. It's hard to find great co-op action these days, and Monaco delivers. I just love that you really have to work together to finish, period. If just one player is dead, you simply cannot progress. It's also fun to have to constantly be saving each other's asses...especially when you have a friend who likes to throw himself into the throes of danger just so he can shout "WHOOOOOOOOOOO!" And then he gets blasted in the face by shotguns.As someone who doesn't even play games that much anymore, Monaco was a delightful surprise that will keep me playing as long as the custom missions keep coming out.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												This is a very unique and awesome stealth game. It has a strong emphasis on co-operative multiplayer gameplay, which more and more games are tapping into, and for the better.As a single-player title, it is not particularly impressive. It has its moments, but for a long while, the game is just too easy. Luckily, it has a lot of challenging and fun levels later on in which you'll actually have to play it stealthy.As a multiplayer game, it is one of the best gaming experiences one can have. I think having 2 players instead of 3 or 4 is still best, but all options are very fun. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a game to play with friends, and also any fans of the stealth genre (like me!).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Monaco has one of the most unique gameplay combinations I have played, its filled with indie pixely goodness, but also has a detailed "stealth" system along with 4 player co-op and a level editor makes for near endless fun. Monaco doesn't let its art style hold it back from telling a story either, throughout the campaign you will learn about the characters and what motivates them. The protagonists are each there own character with there own "personality", something I would think hard to do given the graphical style of the game. I think you should give Monaco a try. Its not an expensive game but it is definitely worth a few bucks!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Okay....I'll admit it.   For a long time I didn't like Monaco because it just felt strange to me.   It's an acquired taste (As one of my friends said in his reviews).But after many heists with friends, I must make a confession....I LOVE THIS BLOODY GAME!!!!!It's not too good in single player, but when you're playing with friends, the chaos becomes your new best friend!You can relate this game to a top-down Metal Gear game, but with a charm of it's own.BRILLIANT story-telling.BEAUTIFUL music.WONDERFUL chaos.FUN gameplay.GREAT mechanics.If this game is not in your library, then why are you even on Steam?!If you meet me in a server, be ready for a good time.   But don't forget........what's yours is mine!

number of helpful: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Not really very good.Too fast paced/arcadey for good cooperation and the artstyle inteferes with gameplay. Certain classes are massively overpowered and others next to useless (a major problem in any coop game).Almost everything you can do in the level (knocking out or even killing guards, hacking computers) resets either after a short timer or when someone finds the body and even the players may be revived infinitely. In addition the vast majority of classes are only really given a small bonus to an ability anyone can do. If anyone can pick a lock being able to pick it slightly faster isn't THAT useful.All of this combined makes it much more likely/effective to simply have each player rush around alone than work together to come up with a proper plan. There is no real punishment for losing players since someone else can do the same thing (though a little more slowly) until you revive them again. Sure you COULD play the game as 'intended' but why? Yes, maybe it does magically get better towards the end but I can't see it being worth the♥♥♥♥♥♥before it. Fixing bad underlying design with 'good' level design is not acceptable.The trailer (video on this store page) is completely unrepresentative of how the actual game plays in coop. As mentioned by others (and indeed at the start of this review) the art style makes it difficult to tell what is actually going on and isn't particularly pretty in its own right.Maybe if you put significant hours into it you'll get used to the art style, only play the 'good' levels/play for score and speed etc but that is not an argument in favour of the game. It is advertised as a cooperative heist game (similar to, say, Swat 4 or Chaos Theory coop in design). Instead it is a fast paced arcade-style game with multiple flaws.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												Greatest lips ever. It was as if they had coldsore blisters all over them. Plus, having multiple lips in the same area is not only enthralling but also endearing. It made everything that much more fun. Never sure if one lip would do what you needed it to at the right time, or noticing as a random lip would quiver and the blisters would pop and spray all over the other lips. Coop at it's best. A shining achievement in blister history. I'd give it five full lip blisters and a quarter pus filled sack -- have fun!

												This is Quite a long review but nevermind...I was and still am a huge fan of monaco but i had onlt completed it on the xbox, and i mean 100% unscathed, bring the bleach all levels completed with all trophies but 1 which was multiplayer and after about 1.5 years i gave up.Then when i bought monaco on the PC i thought it would be nice to try it but i feel the zombies mode has ruined the aspect of monaco, not in the sneaky-ness of it because now you have to be even more sneaky but from the fact the zombies mode seems quite... off for monaco as it is set in france, meant to be a game about stealing (zombies still is but does not feel the same) murder if you can do it silently using a wrench or 7 and getting those SWEET trophies is still there but doing it against the watchmen, THAT HELICOPTER! (you know the one if youve played the game...) and the dogs feels like its proper thievery but against zombies its just collecting coins, a faded screen and 2 zombies called margo and pierre (im assuming the two computer people) just grunting and walking past zombies.*RANT ENDED*But other than that Monaco is a game i will for ever cherish, for its story of which for all my life has never beaten my love for itSOOO... i highly recommend you purchase monaco but if your into completing it as in multiplayer, single player unscathed and cleaned out from head to toe get the xbox version for i think it is better!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This Game is great the enemy AI is unpredictable the levels have a lot of replay value and most importantly the game is hard the first couple levels are fairly simple but in the later levels you really need to experiment with all the diffrent classes and that's some genuinely nice design because at that point the game changes into a stealth puzzle game instead of just a stealh game this genre was never really something I played a lot mainly because I couldn't find any games to play that were based purely on stealth and decision making in most stealth games you can perform takedowns or other things of that type but this game only has one character that can do that which is really great it means you have to rely heavily on your enviroment instead of the normal hey you've got 50 diffrent gadgets that you can use to not get spotted and take this guy down without anybody noticing so yeah long story short this game has it all the sound design ( that actually uses real life sounds ) the character variety, the stealth, etc. so basically to conclude Monaco is a great game and I would recommend it a lot heck I probably forgot like half of the features of this game because there is just so much to talk about and there is a lot of quality to be found in every single one

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
 DISCLAIMER:  This is the first time I write a review, so it's not  that  deep and may have some errors. Have fun!Ah, Monaco. The best place to relax, party, and get robbed by a monkey. This Top-Down 2D game is good, I like it, and like any other game, it has it's  pros  and  cons  . PROS: -Steam Workshop.-Steam Trading cards.-Cheap.-Original.-Nice History.-Nice Graphics. CONS: -Gets boring after you complete the game.-Zombies are sometimes too Overpowered.-Limited tiles and tile placement. (If you do know what I mean..)-There's a part in the history that is too Overpowered.So yeah! That's it. What's yours is mine, and this review, is  mine  . RATING: 9.9/10 - Me.*****/***** - Me.A+ - Me.I recommend the game. It's a good buy.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Monaco is great! Litterally when I was just on the few couple levels I was just confused and screaming since I didn't know what I was doing xDMonaco is addicting, really fun and just wow... xD It really got me into the game where you get in the game and it was just going madman! Straight into to game, heaps of drama while stealing + escaping just got really catchy! Doing different gamemodes and such got pretty fun too I mean who wouldn't like this game? (Except for some people) But Still!Single Player is very challenging but being able to connect with 2-4 players on levels make it easier and also fustrating in a good way. I rate 9/10 because I mean yes it's awesome but there isn't much of variety of levels except for the workshop, but who knows how good the workshop ones are. If you are reading this and are about to buy the game or anything. I REALLY SUGGEST YOU DO!!! *Amazing :D*

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Monaco is a great stealth action-packed game. You take the role of 8 different thieves with very different gameplay through two campaigns and great number of challenges. The gameplay is solid. While you can pretty much force your way through the first levels, you really must avoid getting caught later on. The difficulty of the second campaign is quite hard, with a lot of achivements to go for. While the game is great in solo, it really shines in coop multiplayer, where each player control a different thief. There's also versus multiplayer, which is great fun too. Monaco also has a very fitting soundtrack and a very interesting storyline, mostly because of the way it is told. For those interested, there's also a great deal of community maps made with the very complete level editor in the game. The game recently recieved an update consisting of a reworked campaign and a zombie mode with new enemies. If you like stealth games, monaco really is a blast. I especially recommend it if you can find friends to play with.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												I've never really played a game quite like Monaco. It is more about stealth than it is fighting. It makes you think about where to go next because you might get caught. The soundtrack is amazing. My metaphorical hat goes off to Austin Wintory, the composer. This game is a blast to play with friends. There will be the woe of almost beating a level and then dying because of some stupid reason (example: your friend was AFK.). There will also be the joys of beating a level when you've been working so hard and you know that you have only gotten that far because of the help of your comrades. Single player is also fun because of the thought that you're challenging all these people by yourself. While the graphics seem all pixelated, but they have a certain charm. Oh, and the French voices are a nice touch.9.5/10Complete it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
Not sure what all the hubbub is about.I gave this game two shots to impress me but I just don't see the appeal. First I played it with the keyboard online with a stranger and then the next day I tried it solo with a controller, both sessions were about 45 minutes. I came away from both bored.At its core Monaco is a pretty basic stealth game with a silly tone to it. There's a little bit of story before each level but it doesn't take itself seriously nor should you. I didn't see anything worth caring about. The majority of players probably skip it altogether. The guards you'll spend your time avoiding also have a bumbling way of acting that adds to the droll atmosphere.I did like how each character you choose to play as has a unique special ability that enhances their gameplay in some way. I even enjoyed a few chases at times when I did get caught. However, with most chases I never felt like I was in much danger. I have read that many multiplayer rounds devolve into free-for-all sprints through the level with no regard to stealth and I can see why. There's really only two things to do in each level: collect coins and reach the exit. As far as I can tell coins only add to your score on an online leaderboard which I'm probably not alone in not caring about.Without an interesting story, likable characters, deep gameplay or enjoyable goals to strive for I couldn't find enough to keep me playing Monaco.

												The first thing I tried to do with this game was make it play in windowed mode, because that's how I prefer it. This required me to restart the game.So I did.Then the game opened up in windowed mode, and I tried to drag the game into a corner of my screen, because that's how I prefer it. I got about halfway there before the game stopped loading assets and tried to get into the menu.The game locked up. For a minute. Hitting the red X in the corner to shut it down did absolutely nothing, I had to give it the three finger salute to get it to ♥♥♥♥ off.Subsequent attempts to move the window were entirely futile; I can't even get the game to accept moving the top bar so much as a pixel because as soon as I tab out to get my captured mouse cursor back the game throws a shitfit and locks up HARD.This game is such an attention ♥♥♥♥♥ that if I go outside of the game for so much as a second I have to give it a three finger ♥♥♥♥ you just to get my entire computer back.I don't know what the game is like. I can't even get that ♥♥♥♥ing far in the ♥♥♥♥ing game, because I can't put the game window where I need it to be in order to play.So ♥♥♥♥ this game. content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Probably the worst overhyped game ever made. If you read the other reviews you'll see it's recommended by people with as low as 0.6hrs playtime. So what is Monaco? Monaco is a coin collecting simulator. Imagine pacman, but you've got a gun, and also the ghosts pose 0 threat and don't come back to life. That's Monaco in a nutshell. Stealth? Oh sure, you can stealth through the game. But it's very easy to screw up and set the alarms off, at which point stealth is over and it switches to being one of the easiest shooters ever made. It's just such a laid back game, there's very little consequences for doing anything wrong. The game practically plays itself. Your objective is mainly just to tilt the control stick in the direction of coins then sit back and relax. Want proof Monaco is a poor game? Take a look at the global achievements. Less than 0.9% of people have finished the second act of the campaign; and I'll tell you it's definitely not because it's too hard.It boggles the mind how this game managed to get such amazing reviews as it did; really says a lot about the quality of mainstream reviews nowadays.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Top-down 2D stealth.  It's pretty meh.  The stealth itself is pretty silly with guards getting bored after chasing you, not following you to new areas, and reviving their fellow guards without giving much of a damn.  BUT, it features full 4 player co-op campaign on all levels and full steam workshop support with tons of extra content.  Worth the asking price and could be a fun time running around while setting off hundreds of alarms.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												My thoughts so far:- Alright retro style- Fitting music, but nothing I would look up on YouTube to listen to afterwards.- Seems to have some story, but when playing online with random strangers it's sometimes hard paying attention to it (some people seem to be in a constant rush typing "GO!" all the time in the pre-match readying lobby phase despite you still reading the story text that comes before each map).- Could need more incentives to play stealthy, maybe. You can run/rush through all maps it seems. It turns out real quick and pretty chaotic when playing with random strangers. The difficulty has increased over the course of the maps I've played ("The Lockpick" missions), but not enough to actually force people's speed down. Maybe I need to progress further in it to see even more difficult missions.- Many classes, but not sure if they are equally useful. Some like the Lookout you don't need when running through the maps/when things get loud and none of your teammates care about hiding and going stealthy again. Some like the Hacker appear "overpowered".

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												"Singleplayer or Co-op heist game", key word being singleplayer. No. It's not singeplayer orientated. Singleplayer and co-op have the same maps, same amount of enemies, except you're by yourself. I'm sure this game would be fun with friends to play it, but in my curcumstance this game is not fun, AT ALL. It's massively unbalanced. So much so that it's ridiculous, especially when guards can resurrect each other, despite taking a direct hit to the chest with the full slug from a shotgun. If you like a hard-as-Dark-Souls challenge then by all means buy it, if not don't get it, unless you have friends to play with. At least I got it for $2.54

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Seems like it would be a fun coop game but I just couldn't get over the art style.  It is the worst use of the retro pixel style I have ever seen in a critically acclaimed game. The ugly doesn't bother me so much as it being not functional.  It's a struggle to tell the tile sprites apart while racing through the level: is that a shelf, a wall, a door, or something else?  I don't know, it all looks like placeholder programmer art.   Even after playing for hours I wasn't able to tell what certain things were without stopping and thinking about it.

number of helpful: 47 of 98 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I can appreciate the difficulty in bringing a quality indie concept to fruition, but that doesn't excuse a game from being compelling. At first blush it's a fun little romp which friends can join in on, but it quickly dissolves into an almost meaninglessly easy sprint. It's a stealth game in which stealth is not required, enemies are not particularly lethal, and your characters move blindingly fast. You can easily sprint through all the alarms and trail every guard behind you on the way in and out of each heist, ignore almost all of the loot, and be none the worse for wear. Loot is needed only for high score, and who really cares? All this without mentioning the abilities that make it even easier, especially the Miner character who literally can tunnel around all the obstacles in a level and walk out unscathed. No reason to go stealthy, no reason to really play, actually.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												When I looked at the game in the store, I tought it'll be some kind of a robbery simulator like Payday but with pixel-graphics, also the "field of view" (of the robber) looks gives us a modern-oldschool game, wich I'm a fan of. So I bought this game and started downloading it with a big smile on my face. When the downloading is completed, I opened the game and started a match. I was waiting and people were just joinning and leaving and I couldnt start to play. After I figured out that there's an option to play offline, I started the game. The character had a delay in movement and crosshair (I mean mouse) and the gameplay was all about moving from a place to place, collecting some golden things and avoiding guards (Wich is impossible in some levels). When guards are chasing after you, they will start saying things in French and that's very annoying.  Now let me tell you the pro's and con's:Pro's:1. The game itself looks high-quality and makes a feeling of an old&new game at the same time. 2. Field of view looks very cool and makes the game more "realistic", wich means you cant just notice all the guards, you'll need to look at them somehow.Con's: 1. Gameplay is same, you'll just need to listen to some convention in the start, and then do the mission. The mission are really boring because the lack of content, you'll find yourself interacting with doors / other things. 2. Sounds are really annoying, especially the one that the guards does.3. A really big amout of levels as a story line, wich makes no sense at all. This game may be cool if it was free, I'd better donate to charity the money I wasted on this game.

												I recieved this game as a gift a while ago, and from around 90m of co-op gameplay, I cannot stand this game, not one bit. I liked the layout of the menus and their bright intense color on black, contrasting the giant pixels to the max.However, the gameplay in my opinion is extremely repetitive, and the game kind of "forces" you to stealth the joint.In this I mean how you may have a shotgun, you can go in and blow someone to their pixely skeleton, however note that you can only use it once, before having to collect 10 stupid coins to load another use into your weapon/tool. And by the time I collected 10 coins, I had about 20 stupid Watchmen following me, tripping lasers as I ran, and doctors shooting me with tranquilizer crossbows, which led to me being beaten to death with the deadly forks the Watchmen hold. Sure, you can try to hide in a bush/vent/tree, but by the time I went in one, they followed me to the bush and happened to poke the bush with their forks, leading me to my instant death.The music, in my opinion, is awful, just sounding like an extremely sped up piano ballad, or better yet a 2-year-old banging their hands and arms on every key possible. The graphics are squares. I think everything is a square. Your body is a big square, with a smaller square (the head, which stupidly bobbles left and right any time you move your mouse), and two little squares (the arms) on the side of the big square. Despite this I do like the lighting effects and post-processing. The animations are like pixel ragdolls.. It's strange.There are different characters to choose from, all with different abilities. I thought that it was cool, being able to have a specialty and all. You start off with 4 at the beginning, and get more as you progress through the campaign.Also, I just want to throw out there that if you want to go up a staircase, ladder, etc., you have to "prepare" it first, and once it's "prepared", you need to wait for ALL players to go there in order to go up. Hated waiting.Overall? 4/10.. Others may like this game, but I sure as hell don't. I'll give them points for originality, but that's it. It's not my kind of game.

												Maybe I haven't yet invested enough time in this game to appreciate what it offers, but some friends and I tried to just jump in and we were not enjoying it. YouTube™ Video: DA- Indie-Luminati Secrets EXPOSED!!!

Essentially, there's no hard proof of this game, its creators, or the judges were involved in a massive coverup at the Independant Games Festival at GDC 2010, but there's too many coincidences to just shrug off that this game won anything or got the press it did on merit alone.  There's definitely a nepotistic attitude going on within the "Indie" scene since there's a lot of coincidences and very friendly dealings with the major developers of that scene.  I don't want to support a game that's involved in that.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Monaco is a great concept gone horribly wrong. I got it as part of Humble Bundle 11, even paying extra for it alongside Antichamber. Antichamber is an epic journey into the mind that can't get enough reccomendation from me. Monaco is a failed attempt at a retro looking stealth game about heists. As you start it, it draws a mysterious air around itself, with, I'll admit, a pleasing retro aesthetic. And then you watch the cinematics. They're certainly not what the advertivements show. They're just the characters at hand sitting someplace taking turns spewing out TEXT-BASED dialouge while doing their stupid, 8-bit, repeating animations. The gameplay is clunky, and the retro aesthetic collapses in on itself when you can't tell what's a wall, what's a door, what's a plaza for you to walk into and yell out at the top of your lungs, "HEY GUISE LOOG AND ME IM ROBB N. YOUR BANK!" You can't tell what's going to break line of sight, what's going to get you noticed, what's going to - oh, wait, it doesn't matter, because you can just run past every guard, kill everyone, set off every alarm, ♥♥♥♥ up every lock-pick attempt (oops, that doesn't matter either cos it's just hold down a key and boom, lock picked) The outcome won't change, you won't get more reinforcements thrown at you, you won't lose money, or fail the mission unless every single one of you dies. It just gets more♥♥♥♥♥♥easy if you have a whole gang of friends at your side, because then, with each classes game-breaking ability, you hardly have to do jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ It sadly fails, with all its' promise, at being a good action game, at being a good stealth game, at being a thriller, at being a good co-op game, all failed. The worst part is it's not actively bad, just plain boring, like a McDonalds hamburger: Far overpriced for the bland thing you get. 3/10

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												My friends and I were looking for a co-op stealth game, and we came across Monaco. Quite generously one of them bought a copy for all three of us. We started playing through the main missions, having a lot of fun sneaking through the maps, silently taking out guards and what not. But then we started to realize that you didn't really need to sneak at all. You could simply run the through the level with abosolutely no consequences. In games like Mark of the Ninja or Hitman: Absolution, you're penalized for being seen, and in the latter even penalized for killing non-targets. With no points system in Monaco, there's no incentive to play it stealthily. Outside of a score, the levels themselves don't feel particularly rewarding. Very repetetive and easy to complete. I would recommend this game to a group of friends who just want something to play together and laugh about. However with no need to communicate or strategize I would not recommend this to anyone looking for an in-depth cooperative stealth game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												The game is interesting in it's design.  You select one of a few unique characters with different abilities and attempt to achieve a goal, usually one pertaining to an overarching plot that you uncover as you progress.  Some stories unlock new characters with new abilities that may (or may not) help you during your next mission.  I loved the references and easter eggs in the game.  The developers certain put a lot of thought and creativity into the game.  That, unfortunately, is where the good ends.  The mechanics aren't consistent.  There are times when you can be standing almost right next to a guard who is staring at you and they will not react, even when in LOS.  Other times you can be standing in another room behind a wall walking softly and they suddenly become alert to something nearby (you).  Mixed with the fact that the characters don't have precise controlling (the gun aiming is atrocious), which makes things ridiculous when there are lasers that will trip alarms and the choice between hacking a computer or smashing through a wall is the same motion.  There were plenty of times I was trying to hack a computer right next to a laser and had to frustratingly inch my way up to the console so as not to slide right into the laser (when you let go of your movement key, your character keeps moving a small distance).  With some refinement, I'd say this game would be a most excellent and exciting co-op game.  As it is, me and my friends simply ended up frustrated and just dashing through the level to make it to the escapes or safe zone with no regard to who we alerted.  Needs more work.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												I found this game very interesting and fun.  You strive to collect all the money in a mission (optional objective) while looking for a Trophy case (primary objective) you need to find and escape.  It's like a heist.   The first few hours, I was having a positive experience playing this game.  However, as time goes on, after completing missions here and there,   I have realized that  most of enjoyment I get out of this game are depending on how well-made the missions are.  How fun and challenging they are.   Some missions, I can run around attracting all the guards and still complete the missions,  I realize that isn't fun at all.    So I really suggest to restrict yourself to being a harmless ninja and try to loot everything and escape.  Everything else really fall just short.

number of helpful: 3 of 13 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2013
												"Monaco: What's Yours is Mine" is a top-down, 4-player CO-OP stealth/heist game inspired by the Oceans Eleven movies. Some have described the game a mix between stealth and PacMan, it being top-down and having to collect coins. PlotSeveral talented people felt they were wronged in their past lives and turned to crime claiming that the world "owed them a debt". Inevitably, all are arrested, and happen to be placed in the same prison where they consolidate their efforts. They meet a crimelord known only as "The Gentleman"; a master of disguise, and are forced to help him rebuild his life after he too lost everything in exchange for a way out of Monaco, France, away from the police, and - finally - freedom. The dialogue is interesting and each character is given enough of a personality to be enjoyable without flooding the player with text. The story isn't too complicated, but it's few twists are enough to make you lean back in your chair and exclaim "No, way!" It's very well written and was a delight to hear.GraphicsThe fastest and easiest way to describe the graphics would be Minecraft's blocky, pixlated look. The visuals and art are wonderfully inspired and fun to watch. Same for the game's goofy animations (My favorite being the Red-Head girl's wave. A long, black stick represents her arm with a small block shifting left to right at the top. Another is the "head box" of the toons' body sliding left to right across the "body box" to look around.) Levels are colorful eye candy without being cluttered and hindering vision. The layout is still believable i.e. desks are in the right places, the insane asylum's layout makes sense and so on. Even the menus are well polished, organized, and easy to navigate. Unfortunately, you can't "click" on anything. Sorry, PC fans; it's the age of console ports. Arrow keys and Enter keys it is. SoundPerhaps Monaco's most proud feature is the sound design. From opening shafts/doors, to gathering/using items, the sound design is spot-on. Even when you die, you leave behind a skeleton that can be revived by allies. While being revived, it literally sounds like they are pouring flesh and blood back into you! It's so great!....if not, sometimes a little gross. The voice acting is equally commendable. Although our theiving protagonists don't make a peep beyond heavily breathing when their health is low, the guards are well-voiced and their dialogue is in pure french. Hearing a guard go "What was that?" can get old when it's in your native language, but hearing it in a foreign tongue makes the same line suprisingly facinating! However, beyond all this is the TRUE pride of Monaco's sound: the music. While undetected, the music is mostly piano that rouses a combination of silliness, and stealth. The tunes are dulcet with a personality of it's own. When you're caught, the music morphs to a reminiscent sound of Chaplin-esque, ragtime music. Imagine this: you and 3 friends lay out a detailed and complex plan of how to tackle the next puzzle, but EVERYTHING goes wrong! The alarm sounding, the guards sprinting to the scene, you and your team are panicking as you scramble to get away, slowly opening vent shafts and scurrying into bushes while this music plays. It's a feeling I can't describe beyond "masterpiece". So rarely does music and gameplay weave together to make such immersion like this. GameplayAll of the above would be wasted on a game if it's gameplay wasn't good, right? Monaco's gameplay is simple, yet brilliant. It plays very "simply" but is far from casual. The goal is to take an objective always symbolized as a giant trophy, but you can only unlock the next mission by gathering all the coins on said mission. You have a main ability, a secondary ability, the weapon/tool you take, and sneaking. That's it. Sounds shallow? In fact, it's not. The simple mechanics of the game leave it to be very controllable and follow a tight meta of teamwork. Therein is the brilliance of the simplicity. Some examples are: The Lockpick. He picks locks the fastest (omg nowai??) and his secondary is he opens safes and cash registers the fastest. The Look Out (My personal favorite) can spot enemies with radar-like precision across the entire map. She also unveils "shroud" to reveal the level to the otherwise blind team. Her secondary ability is to open vent shafts the fastest, providing an escape route for the whole team. Lastly mentioned is the Cleaner who can knock out guards if they aren't too suspicious of him. His secondary is using health kits the fastest. There's several more, but you get the idea. They are all powerful, yet not omnipotent, forcing a reliance on others without making anyone feel useless. Teamwork in games is rarely captured this perfectly. The online functionality is also smooth as butter. Connecting to games is a breeze and I rarely experience lag that breaks the game.The VerdictMonoco: What's Yours is Mine is a superb display of game design, sound design, and gameplay mechanics. Charming visuals, hilarious and honeyed music, perfect sound, low price, and well polished gameplay make for a game that can't be refused. Monaco earns the coveted 10 out of 10 from me! It's that elusive indie gem we've all been searching for!

Posted: May 21, 2016
												I have been looking forward to playing this game since I grabbed a copy during the Steam sale at Christmas.  To say that I feel like I've been ripped off, even though this game only cost me £1.55 is an understatement.The art style is nice, but it's not easy to see what's going on, and very confusing.  I hate the idea of co-op play on any game, but this game is built around it.  Also, there is never little in the way of telling you what to do, and what is going on.  When you start a game for the first time you except a mini tutorial just to get you started and introduced to some of the basic game mechanics.  No such luck here.This game will live in my game library, and I doubt I'll ever fire it up again.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Monaco will test your skill in timing, planning and hiding as fast as you can. Teamplay is highly encouraged as different classes bring variety to the gameplay. The campaign is plenty long and will not disappoint. And if you're one to collect every last coin, you will definitely be in for a challenge.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Extremely fun and challenging multiplayer game, with the right combination of stressfulness and entertainment that keeps you wanting to play it. I haven't had a whole lot of play time with it, but that's mostly because I want to experience the game with a full party and not just by myself like a lonely loser. Playing with friends is surprisingly balanced for a multiplayer game, and even if everyone has different classes, the game is still difficult and it requires a lot of communication and coordination with your team to get through the heists - that is, if you plan on getting out with everyone alive. Very nice, very pretty, very fun, I can't say I have a single bad thing to say about this game. 10/10 would play again.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Monaco is one of my favorite games, and probably will remain so. From my perspective, its meant to be played co-op and not too seriously. Because it doesn't take itself too seriously. You and three of your friends (or three strangers on the internet) get to run, hide, steal, and generally cavort your way through tons of zany levels. And due to the amazing level editor, the content does not stop when you finish the story mode. Its tons of fun, so go buy it! You won't be disappointed. This game knows that even without the most advanced graphics, perks, or features, its all about gameplay, and Monaco's gameplay cannot be beat.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												To call Monaco a stealth game would be like calling a dandelion food. While technically it is, if you are eating a flower you are probably doing it wrong. In the same way, Monaco is more of a cooperitive game then a stealth game. That isn't to say that it's a bad stealth game, in fact it's one of the best that I've ever played. It just that it's so much better with friends. The best parts of the game are when one player saves the rest of the party and completely turn the hiest around. Even playing online is better than playing solo. So if you are looking to spend a weekend with friends, this is the game to play.

												Monaco is the best online multiplayer game released in 2013. The gameplay is addictive and challenging. Posted: January 6, 2014
												This game is absolutely fantastic. The ambiance is wonderful, with the music, the guards and NPCs actually speaking french, the vibrant colors contrasting with gray and black, it's really amazing.And the game is SUPER fun, especially when you can get a couple of friends to play with. Nothing is more satisfying than cleaning a place out with a bunch of friends, or pulling off the impossible when saving them in a terrible situation with a combination of stealth, smoke bombs or your character's skills. Walking around the map just avoiding, deactivating the security, dodging guards and running off with the loot, it's all fantastic. Sometimes we start a game thinking, yeah we'll just play a bit, but a few hours later we're still at it. This game can get intense and you just really get into it.If you're wondering if you should buy it, yes you should. I got it on sale, but imo it's 100% worth the full price.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Monaco has the stealth, thievery, backstabbing, and all the rest iconic of it's genre, mixed with the chaotic teamwork that comes from a multiplayer indie. After joining a lobby and choosing a thief to play as, all 4 players are dropped in the entry zone of the mission with a common goal, but different ways to do it. While the mole slowly digs around the conflict, The Locksmith is running for his life from the melee police, the hacker is running to every power point and computer, building an army of viruses, and the pickpocket is using the disguise he found in the guards locker to walk among the rich peacefuls as his monkey hauls in the loot. Next mission: The gentleman is darting from cover to cover, trying to get there before the guards see through his rapidly disentegrating disguise, the redhead noob is trying to to get the guard she has charmed to fight the angry guards shooting at her, and the cleaner is using chloroform on everything between him and the dead lookout he is trying to revive. Once they have gotten back together, The Gentleman stumbles into a laser tripwire and accidentally kills everyone with TNT. The Lookout says he should have gone hacker and the others quit the game. In case you missed my point, the pure chaos of the game mixed with the number of ways to play makes it well worth the cost (while the sale lasts)

Posted: December 11, 2013
												This is one of those games where you can come up to me in, like, 20 years, and say "Hey, wanna go a few rounds in Monaco?" and I'll be all like, "DO I?!?!?" and we'll play all night long and eat chee-tos and be bestest friends. That's how good this game is. Single player is okay, but multiplayer is where it's at. Don't be fooled into thinking this is a straight stealth game, either! This is a game where getting caught and going "Screw it, grab the loot and GO!" is just as much fun as pulling off a perfect heist. I haven't played multiplayer online yet, but I can't imagine it getting much better than playing with your friends in the same room and on the same screen. You should get this game so we can play together. Or better, come over and bring a wired xbox controller so we can get some 3-player action going!

Posted: December 12, 2013
												I can't recommend this game enough. Screenshots and videos really just don't capture how well the game recreates the hiest feeling. I've played multiple runs and still revisit it from time to time.In addition to the gameplay the writing is very compelling. The string of hiests follow an appropriate plot with an Rashomon-esque retelling. Though the story would have been interesting on its own it was definitely enhanced by its fusion with the gameplay.Monaco's greatest weakness is that the game tragically degrades in quality when playing by yourself. The formula really shines when you're going at it with friends whether it's using slick coordination or frantically fleeing death.I highly recommend this game if you'll have people to play with. Otherwise it's probably not worth your time.
