Posted: April 21, 2014
												Wysiwygbaby! This game is great. It mixes an interesting story filled with humor and intrigue with fun and challenging gameplay.Monaco allows players to work together with friends or randomly matched online players to attempt to pull off some of the biggest heists the world has ever seen. A selection of characters, each with their own special abilities and personalities, are available for players to choose from to assemble their team. Each level offers new challenges that the team must overcome in order to succeed in pulling off the perfect heist. The game gets hard, particularly in the second plot arc, but it never really gets frustrating. Even when you end up botching a mission terribly, you tend to have a good time doing it. Then it's a matter of reorganizing your strategy, maybe picking up different characters, and throwing yourself back into the breach.The only complaint I have is that some levels seem almost too hard to complete without a full 4-man team. It's simple enough to pick up online players when one does not have enough friends to fill out a party, but sometimes you really just want to play with one or two other people.Overall, whether you are making it to the getaway car with health bars to spare or getting mauled by guard dogs, playing Monaco is always a good experience.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Monaco is a difficult game to describe because it doesn't fall into a well-tread genre, but it's part puzzle game, part top-down action game, and overall a lot of fun. Up to four players form a team of criminals attempting a heist, and the game is a race to collect all of the money and treasure without getting caught by the gaurds. It's heavily designed around online multiplayer, and the open lobby system makes it easy to get matched up with random partners in crime.One of the best things about the game is how it handles difficulty and varying player skill. Aside from levels that get progressively harder as the storyline unfolds, success in each mission is less about getting through the mission at all and more about doing it as quickly and effeciently as possible. So if you end up with a mix of veteran players and n00bs, everyone can still do their own thing and feel like they are contributing even if some players are doing more of the work. The time/speedrun system works well for replayability, because once you become better at the game it's a lot of fun to use your new skills to plow through some of the earlier levels.There are eight different characters in the game all with different abilities, and the balance between characters is pretty good so that there are not obvious best and worst characters. Also each level has different aspects that can make certain characters more advantageous, although it's always possible to complete the levels with any set characters. There's also an entertaining and somewhat convoluted storyline for the game that gives each character a unique personality.The core gameplay and level design are both top notch and that's why the game makes you want to keep playing levels to try for better times. I would recommend it to anyone who likes action-y games, especially if you are looking for an online co-op game. Even for people who don't generally like online multiplayer games it can be a good intro into that kind of game because you can start out as a novice and not feel like you're in way over your head. Great game and I look forward to more games from Pocketwatch.

It may take a little bit to learn the game, but there are enough "classes" so you can find your niche. Playing it with friends makes it feel rewarding and worth it. I would definitely recommend this game if you and your buddies had a weekend to blow on a fantastic game.

												Monaco has very simple mechanics: walk into things to use them, line of sight the gaurds/civs, and steal everything of value. The classes pretty much do the same thing as the next class can do but are specialized in some actions. Locksmith picks locks and safes fast, Pickpocket hides in bushes fast, etc etc. Some classes have special abilities as well, like Mole can dig into most walls, Redhead can charm enemies, etc etc.Unlike most stealth games, Monaco doesn't end when you're seen. Your score isn't based on how stealthy you are, but how fast you cleared the level with coins missed adding time. It's a ton of fun when you're with 4 people, alarms are going off, and everybody is disorganized.Despite the simple mechanics, it's a challenging game. Towards the end you're up against SWAT guys with shotguns who can pretty much 2-3 shot you from accross the room so STAY HIDDEN!UPDATE DEC 21 '13: I should note that the game comes out with free updates. Last update came new game mechanics like pickpocketing keys off gaurds to unlock doors in the mission or "buttcash" (people used to stand on top of coins, now they have wallets) which should have been in the game from the start but is in now. Last update also nerfed some of the difficulty in a lot of the missions in order to allow for all players to get through the game.

Posted: June 2, 2013
												I admit, I haven't been following Monaco's epic sucess story since the beginning (I actually bought the game on a whim after seeing all the raved reviews), but I do know a thing or two about the game's past. It's the winner of the IGF 2010 grand prize, and that was THE SAME IGF HOLDING FEZ AND THE BINDING OF ISAAC (I think). Now, it's a full-fledged game. The story is a classic story of a bunch of criminals trying to escape Monaco. Stealth is challenging, collecting all of the coins can make your life hell, and the characters all feel unique with specific designs and special abilities. The one thing I didn't like about the game was the art style, because, contrary to the popular belief, I feel that it only really worked for characters and not the environment. Overall, 9/10.

Posted: March 8, 2014
												This game is wonderful with friends. Plan your moves carefully, craft a clever plan to get the goods undetected and then bask in glow of your accomplishment as you pull it off. Or, more often than not, go on a frenzied panic-fuelled run through the level as you try to lose the angry pursuers. And this is the real strength of the game - having your elaborate (or not, as the case may be) plan fall to pieces does not mean it's time to restart. It means it's time to think on your feet. And that's often more fun.The various classes all distinguish themselves, though some are clearly more or less suited to some levels. The visuals can initially be confusing but it grows on you.

Posted: April 3, 2014
												Monaco is an interesting game. It's straight forward gameplay, and level design really sold it for me. Due to the fact that each player has different abilities, each player has a specific role to play. Working as a team takes practice and timing, but is really rewarding at the same time. Yet, you could also just run loose and have crazy missions which are equally as fun.The only areas of the map that you'll see in color is your field of vision, so get use to black and grey layouts. While I haven't beaten this game 100% completely, it is still in my top 25 games.The only problem I had with it is that finding a group to play with can be difficult at times, and if you lack any way to communicate, then you'll have to play the game by ear.Overall I give it a 4/5.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												This is a backlog review for me of a game played in 2016 that came out much earlier.  It's not meant to reflect the release experience of the game, but merely how i feel playing it for my own enjoyment as almost sunk cost in 2016.Gameplay: 6/10.  It's actually pretty fun to solve these 2d stealth puzzles and collect the coins.  There's nearly no variety between the classes that makes me feel like I'm doing something special or cooperative in the heists.  There aren't any customization options to speak of.  There's no depth in the stealth-alert system.  There is no real distinguishing features between the weapons or loadouts.  It's very simple.  There's no plot to speak of, and it doesn't feel like I'm engaged in the gameplay.Sound: 9/10.  The sound is beautiful.  The french classique motif is really fun and engaging.  It holds the whole game together with how immersive it is.  You'll enjoy the patois of french-english that the characters speak as you surprise them.Graphic Presentation:  6/10.  It's pixel art, but it works.  They've designed the game in a way that has good humor from the pixel art system, and the whimsy from the pixel art goes top down through the rest of the game.  It's objectively well presented as pixel, but it still feels like other games have improved on this system and done a lot more with the 2D stealth genre (such as Klei's near-perfect Invisible, Inc. to which this game invites comparison).  I will further add that the pixel art is necessary to the presentation of the game, rather than being a result of cost-cutting laziness, and I have considered that and awarded score for the unity of the styling instead of detracting because it is so simple.Replayability: 4/10.  There's really just not much here.  There are a few maps that you can go through, collect coins and attempt to get a good timed score.  You're pulling off 2-D heists, but there is absolutely, and I mean absolutely no challenge.  It's fun for an hour or two, but honestly it feels like these people are letting you take their stuff.  The characters are rough sketches of heist tropes, and while games like Team Fortress 2 have trope characters that have great personalities that engage with sketch humor and are very memorable (the Heavy coming immediately to mind), Monaco's characters are all really bland.  The Gentleman doesn't make you feel like he's above everyone else.  The Safecracker isn't an obsessive compuslive cretin.  The Lookout has almost no lines at all.Overall: 6/10.  It's cute.  It's fun.  You'll have two hours of fun, maybe more out of it.  It might be fun to play with some friends that are very casual gamers, or you could get your little sibling to play with you.  There is room for a nice and easy casual puzzle game.  When you compare it to better games in its genre, like Invisible, Inc., or better pixel multiplayer games, like Risk of Rain, or very casual cooperative games, like Terraria or Trine, it just falls short.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Monaco has the stealth, thievery, backstabbing, and all the rest iconic of it's genre, mixed with the chaotic teamwork that comes from a multiplayer indie. After joining a lobby and choosing a thief to play as, all 4 players are dropped in the entry zone of the mission with a common goal, but different ways to do it. While the mole slowly digs around the conflict, The Locksmith is running for his life from the melee police, the hacker is running to every power point and computer, building an army of viruses, and the pickpocket is using the disguise he found in the guards locker to walk among the rich peacefuls as his monkey hauls in the loot. Next mission: The gentleman is darting from cover to cover, trying to get there before the guards see through his rapidly disentegrating disguise, the redhead noob is trying to to get the guard she has charmed to fight the angry guards shooting at her, and the cleaner is using chloroform on everything between him and the dead lookout he is trying to revive. Once they have gotten back together, The Gentleman stumbles into a laser tripwire and accidentally kills everyone with TNT. The Lookout says he should have gone hacker and the others quit the game. In case you missed my point, the pure chaos of the game mixed with the number of ways to play makes it well worth the cost (while the sale lasts)

												When I first got Monaco , I found it boring. I'm not an experienced gamer , and didn't know much about Monaco itself . I struggled a bit and didn't know how to go online .However , after about half a year of not playing it , I decided to give it another go . I loved it . I was hit with an exciting stealth game , which was cunningly designed . I adore the look of the game and its great how each character has its own little personality. But I have to say online mode is the best . Its not about stealth - its about set all the alarms of and run . I must've spent hours online playing with people all around the world , howling with laughter one minute , then reviving a player the next minute. The whole design of the game mixed with the beautiful music makes it a really good game to play alone , or multiplayer . Apart from the occasional crash ( after returning to desktop a few times it fixes it ) ,and not being able to make my own levels ( for some reason this just didn't work ) the whole game ran smoothly for me . I definately reccomend this game to anyone !

Posted: January 2, 2014
												A top-down third person version of the Payday series, Monaco is a great game to pick up and play among friends. Relatively easy to learn as well and has a variety of game modes and community mods to ensure you neevr get bored.The mechanics of the game are fairly simplistic and easy to understand and remain constant for most parts of the game. The only thing that needs improvement would probably be the connection system. It took me 20 mins on my first try to create a room and start a game with friends. The gameplay afterwards made this mishap relatively forgiving though.8/10, strongly recommended for groups of friends of all ages.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												A Definate Must-Play.Monaco is one of those games that put itself out there to try something new, and it made it through. Monaco, like Minecraft or Team Fortess 2, is one of those games that were inovative and risked being criticized for leaving that line of what has become the cliche' of modern gaming. It is a game of skill and precision, you can't go around kill everything... well... actually, you can, but I wouldn't consider it. Sure, it's not anything to compete against espionage of today like the god-forbidden Splinter Cell, and whatever happened to it's dignity, or Metal Gear Solid, but it is completely worth the $15, it is intensly fun, especially with friends.I recommend that you and a friend buy this game, it's a really good way to spend an afternoon.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a stealth/action singleplayer & co-op game developed by Pocketwatch Games featuring eight playable characters, each with their own specialty, as well as a lot of levels within the campaigns to keep one busy for hours on end (not including the MANY user-created levels made with the very well-done built-in level creator). Playing the levels with each character is like a different experience on it's own, which doesn't include the experience you and your friends could enjoy with the awesome co-op. Add to that Monaco can be (and is for me) a VERY addicting game with a nice soundtrack that fits completely and you have yourself a game worth every penny. Buy it now or it'll be your loss!

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Really good with a friend or two. I wouldn't recommend getting it if you're going to be playing alone, but if you have a friend, definitely think about picking Monaco up. The game has a substantial amount of content for its relatively low price. Took me about 8 hours to finish the main campaign. After you complete the main campaign, a "hard mode" of sorts is unlocked, featuring maps from the original campaign, just with a higher difficulty. There are also bonus maps added in an update. Everything considered, I think you should be able to expect at least 15 hours of content.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is a fun, exciting game. It's not Payday, nor is it Left 4 Dead, but it's a fast paced multiplayer experience just the same. While it may be tough to get into if you're not used to overhead 2D graphics, it's quite enjoyable once you get used to it.My main greivance is the lack of a single player mode, and that you need to play with others. If you're as bad as I am, it's embarrasing to die in front of others. Yet, I understand that programming AI for a heist game is pretty tough, and must be even more so for indie devs.If you're not into playing face paced, quick games; this is not the game for you. However, if you're willing to give it a try, you'll find this game to be more than enjoyable, and what it lacks in a single player mode, it more than makes up for in the artistic sytle and captivating environment and music it provides.Overall, I give it a 4.25/5.

												This is my favorite game i've found on steam so far. Basically it is a stealth game, with great co-op and pvp multiplayer, where you basically conduct heists. The single player is also fun, but if you buy this game it is for the multiplayer. There are eight playable characters (four of which you unlock)  all with varying skills and abilities. And on top of all of that it has a great story, told by different points of view, but it is easy to understand without even reading the dialogue. Get it so we can play! 8/10

Posted: July 12, 2013
												Monaco is a whismical, colorfully violent game.  It boasts an intriguing story, one-of-a-kind art direction and soundtrack, and the kind of cooperative gameplay and mechanics we haven't seen since Gauntlet: Dark Legacy.  It improves on that formula in almost every aspect, bringing true cooperation to the modern era outside of Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2.  Every character has their own distincy personality, color and playstyle, and it's super fun to figure out which one would be best for each encounter.  A single round can turn from meticulous planning to outright chaos in seconds, and no matter how you play, it's just a blast.    And what's even cooler, is that the community is the most civil I've ever seen.  Perhaps it's the lack of a competitive element, or how it's impossible to do well solo, but people just love this game, and are super cool about who plays as who.  TL;DR:  BUY THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Every positive review of this game is spot-on, but I just didn't like it as much as I hoped.I love 2d retro games, but Monaco (single player mode) quickly came to feel repetitive. The characters are actually very diverse, and the life system (losing one character allows continuing with a different one from the same stage) forces you to adapt and make long-term strategies.But eventually every level felt like "hide as long as you can, then run as fast as you can, then hide until they forget you. Rinse wash and repeat."The developers did a great job, but Monaco has made me wary of future purchases based just on cool graphics and a neat concept.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Monaco is one of those titles that comes around only every so often...It's a fast paced single/multiplayer heist game filled with nonsensical shenanigans that will keep you coming back for more each time. Regardless of if you play the campaign alone or with friends it's definitely a purchase worth investing in for the long term. You'll see yourself going through the levels again and again for either new experiences or to finish higher in the leaderboards that are availible. Sometimes you'll find yourself running around like crazy as guards or agents chase after you to throw you in the slammer...other times you'll approach the level very stealthily with little or no contact with the NPCs in the game. Monaco offers a variety of ways to achieve it's one goal which is to get the loot/gold to complete the level and to get the hell out of there! Whether or not you like the art style or even some of the other small nuances of the game it's definitely worth the buy to try out! (Personally I give it a 4.5/5, one of the best 2D co-operative games out there in terms of indie games).

Posted: December 20, 2014
												Monaco is a neon-blooded marriage of Pac-Man and Thief, a grand tribute both to 1920s silent comedy capers and to modern-day heist movies. It's Ocean's Eleven meets Keystone Cops, played out top-down in a world of living blueprints. It's a criminal take on Laurel and Hardy, except with a four-man band instead of the dysfunctional duo. By and large, Monaco is one of those rare games that somehow stay magnificent regardless of whether you're getting things right or your mission has turned into an eight-lane car crash."Monaco stays magnificent regardless of whether you're getting things right."And crashes of the non-software-related variety will happen in abundance. With Monaco's minimal approach to player guidance, the only way you're going to figure anything out is through trial and disaster. Have a Hacker (one of the game's many playable characters) interact with a power outlet and watch as sensors go out and security cameras turn friendly. Walk across a red panel and discover that there are, indeed, pressure plates connected to the security system.The missions are all performed to a similar tune: get in, get the prize, get out. Or, in some instances, simply get out. You start in a safe area of the level, surrounded by items that you can take along with you. Once you've selected your weapon (or non-combat item of choice), it is your prerogative to determine what 'getting in' will actually entail. Do you cut through a queue at the local nightclub or do you sneak through a locked door on the other side? Though all the levels operate in largely the same way, there's sufficient diversity in the contents of each to make every playthrough outright enthralling. Should you circle around the main area of the map and inch towards the safe on the third floor, or do you take a quick detour through the guard-infested inventory room? (Hint: don't do that second one.) Your choice, your years behind bars, monsieur.

Posted: July 14, 2014
Monaco is a top-down stealth/action game. I had a lot of fun with it, but it can be boring under the wrong circumstances. tl;dr: this is a top-down tactical stealth game, it's by far the most fun with a friend in 2-player mode, and you should experiment with different characters.Single-player runs are a bit too predictable and straightforward, and every mission will feel just like more of the same thing. Multiplayer is much more interesting - it's moments like sneaking in to steal the treasure while a friend stands guard and another hacks the security, or splitting up to clean out an entire floor within a minute, that make this game worth playing.On the other hand, groups of too many (inexperienced) players are likely to get in each others' way and spend too much time being discovered to get anything done. Two coordinated, voice-chatting players are the best for combining your characters' abilities successfully and pulling off your own strategy together.On the other hand: While smooth and coordinated runs are very satisfying, it can also be fun to treat Monaco as a party game and frantically stumble through a level with four players and swarms of guards behind you.The graphics are stylish, unique and do their purpose, but a bit taxing on the eyes and take a while to get used to. The music fits the heist setting, but there's not enough of it. The story also helps to set the mood, and while it's not important, I'm glad that it's there because it gives the missions context.Stealing money slowly grants you additional tool uses/ammunition, so raiding optional rooms is actually rewarded within missions and it can be advantageous to do so and e. g. gather additional EMP charges before taking on the main vault's motion detectors.This means that while skilled maneuvering is still a focal point, threat assessment and careful planning are just as essential.While the core stealth gameplay always remains similar, the 8 characters' special abilities have a huge influence on which path and approach you can take to beating the level. One team may allow you to tunnel towards the objective past a large portion of the treasure and just run past the guards that remain in your way, while another one relies on luring them one by one and knocking them out so no one's even awake to answer the alarm.Monaco is fairly forgiving for a stealth game - getting detected early on hardly ever means having to restart a level in advance.It does get kind of boring how easily you can disperse attention by crawling into ventilation ducts and waiting.The normal price is a bit high because the game only shines if you buy a second copy for a friend, but I very highly recommend buying this when it's on sale if you're into strategic, sometimes chaotic co-op action.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												For me Monaco is the Game of the Year 2013 and it's also one of the best games I've ever played. Whether you like to play games casually or competitively, Monaco delivers them big time. Just when you have 100% completed the game with your sneaky and stealthy strategies you will find out that there is also a lively speedrunning community which tries to push quickness to it's limits all the time and all over again. You cannot even think of how competitive this game is after you have grinded one level for hours just to get that world record. Moreover, if you have friends to play with the fun is suddenly doubled. Planning crazy heists or speedruns with friends absurdly pleasant and after you get fed up with your constantly dying team mates you can turn them into foes in multiple PvP maps!All in all, Monaco is tons of fun and laugh no matter how you play it. It's definitely worth couple of bucks (and it's on sale ALL THE FREAKING TIME) and for me one of the best video games I've ever witnessed.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Every positive review of this game is spot-on, but I just didn't like it as much as I hoped.I love 2d retro games, but Monaco (single player mode) quickly came to feel repetitive. The characters are actually very diverse, and the life system (losing one character allows continuing with a different one from the same stage) forces you to adapt and make long-term strategies.But eventually every level felt like "hide as long as you can, then run as fast as you can, then hide until they forget you. Rinse wash and repeat."The developers did a great job, but Monaco has made me wary of future purchases based just on cool graphics and a neat concept.

Posted: June 3, 2015
												I like and respect this game. Unfortunately, a lot of the multiplayer community is gone, which leaves the cooperative aspect fairly limited.Edit: The multiplayer community comes and goes when this game goes on sale.Why I like it: Gameplay is how you choose to play, which gives a great open environment feel that lets an action game be an adventure game if you want it to be. As you progress into the story, there's a lot of flexibility on how you can play, which even furthers this feeling of open environment. Almost anything can be destroyed or mined through, and can, in some regards, be looked at as a scaled down, 2D version of Payday.Why I respect it: This game is the embodiment of the idea that not all great games need great models. A lot of the game is basic pixels scaled up. There are no flashy skins or gorgeous maps. The atmosphere fits the game perfectly, and playing it just feels right. It's hard to explain why this game feels good to play - stealth, fighting, sneaking around, all packed into an 8-bit-style game about robbery.As a single player experience, it's not bad. But where this game really shines is multiplayer.

Posted: June 11, 2015
												Monaco, What's Yours Is Mine. And Monaco... is mine!A fun and colorful game, with multiple characters with different special abilities to play as.Monaco is a great stealth game, but when you get caught & the alarms go off, it really shines because you're not immediately screwed -- you have options & abilities and the game lets you use them how you like.The thematic elements, the jazzy piano soundtrack, the flexibility-vs-constraints come together for a great game to play.Play with good stereo headphones on -- you'll be able to hear the direction of nearby footsteps of NPCs even if you can't see them on-screen.Play with friends, over voice chat!  just like Ocean's 11 or any team-heist movie you're set up for a good time when working together and using misdirection (or just havoc!) to bail each other out of a FUBAR situation.If you've wanted to star in a heist movie, and you enjoy fun, this game is for you. B-)

Posted: July 14, 2014
Monaco is a top-down stealth/action game. I had a lot of fun with it, but it can be boring under the wrong circumstances. tl;dr: this is a top-down tactical stealth game, it's by far the most fun with a friend in 2-player mode, and you should experiment with different characters.Single-player runs are a bit too predictable and straightforward, and every mission will feel just like more of the same thing. Multiplayer is much more interesting - it's moments like sneaking in to steal the treasure while a friend stands guard and another hacks the security, or splitting up to clean out an entire floor within a minute, that make this game worth playing.On the other hand, groups of too many (inexperienced) players are likely to get in each others' way and spend too much time being discovered to get anything done. Two coordinated, voice-chatting players are the best for combining your characters' abilities successfully and pulling off your own strategy together.On the other hand: While smooth and coordinated runs are very satisfying, it can also be fun to treat Monaco as a party game and frantically stumble through a level with four players and swarms of guards behind you.The graphics are stylish, unique and do their purpose, but a bit taxing on the eyes and take a while to get used to. The music fits the heist setting, but there's not enough of it. The story also helps to set the mood, and while it's not important, I'm glad that it's there because it gives the missions context.Stealing money slowly grants you additional tool uses/ammunition, so raiding optional rooms is actually rewarded within missions and it can be advantageous to do so and e. g. gather additional EMP charges before taking on the main vault's motion detectors.This means that while skilled maneuvering is still a focal point, threat assessment and careful planning are just as essential.While the core stealth gameplay always remains similar, the 8 characters' special abilities have a huge influence on which path and approach you can take to beating the level. One team may allow you to tunnel towards the objective past a large portion of the treasure and just run past the guards that remain in your way, while another one relies on luring them one by one and knocking them out so no one's even awake to answer the alarm.Monaco is fairly forgiving for a stealth game - getting detected early on hardly ever means having to restart a level in advance.It does get kind of boring how easily you can disperse attention by crawling into ventilation ducts and waiting.The normal price is a bit high because the game only shines if you buy a second copy for a friend, but I very highly recommend buying this when it's on sale if you're into strategic, sometimes chaotic co-op action.

												Monaco is a great reminder that games can be played exactly the way you want to play them. I loved the Ocean's movies and the feel of sneaking around the whole level makes you feel like a true robber. The single player experience is really great but it becomes infinitely better with friends. There is never one way to complete a level and most of the time you find out that your "great plan" backfires within 30 seconds. It's really satisfying to try to improve your technique through each level and the mayhem that occurs with friends is unmatched in a co-op expirence.

Multiplayer is much more interesting - it's moments like sneaking in to steal the treasure while a friend stands guard and another hacks the security, or splitting up to clean out an entire floor within a minute, that make this game worth playing.On the other hand, groups of too many (inexperienced) players are likely to get in each others' way and spend too much time being discovered to get anything done. Posted: November 2, 2015
												Oh my god.Monaco is possibly one of my favorite games to just pick up and play. The early levels are usually 5-10 minutes, with most levels being about 20 minutes, and maybe 30 minutes on the later levels.The game is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥in solo. Don't buy it to play alone. If you're going to buy this game, make sure some friends have it too.Each character has a special skill, all of which are useful for the current situation. (Except the Pickpocket and Locksmith, they're only good for a speedrun)There are 4 chapters, each told by a different character, and each one escalating in difficulty from the last. Notably, there are 3 versions of every level- Monaco 2013 has the original levels before updates were made, and Zonaco replaces all NPCs with zombies.The entire game is orchestrated by Austin Wintory's fantastic soundtrack(Discotheque Rouge is the best), and let's be honest, how many games feature ragtime in their soundtrack?

There are a variety of different levels and eneymy types, keeping the gameplay fresh even in singleplayer, though this game is best played with friends. Stealth is your best friend in this game, and getting caught is almost always your faultI'd recommend this game to anyone who wants a good heist game

Posted: June 3, 2015
												I like and respect this game. Unfortunately, a lot of the multiplayer community is gone, which leaves the cooperative aspect fairly limited.Edit: The multiplayer community comes and goes when this game goes on sale.Why I like it: Gameplay is how you choose to play, which gives a great open environment feel that lets an action game be an adventure game if you want it to be. As you progress into the story, there's a lot of flexibility on how you can play, which even furthers this feeling of open environment. Almost anything can be destroyed or mined through, and can, in some regards, be looked at as a scaled down, 2D version of Payday.Why I respect it: This game is the embodiment of the idea that not all great games need great models. A lot of the game is basic pixels scaled up. There are no flashy skins or gorgeous maps. The atmosphere fits the game perfectly, and playing it just feels right. It's hard to explain why this game feels good to play - stealth, fighting, sneaking around, all packed into an 8-bit-style game about robbery.As a single player experience, it's not bad. But where this game really shines is multiplayer.

												Initially I put off playing this one because I figured I knew what it was already.  And while my guess wasn't too far off, it didn't account for just how much fun it would be.  You get to play as one of a number of different criminal roles (locksmith, mole, lookout, etc.) as you attempt heists, prison breakouts, etc.  In a way, it almost feels like a multiplayer version of Bonanza Bros, which not a whole lot of people probably remember.  Definitely fun and way more fun when playing multiplayer.

Posted: April 15, 2015
												Monaco is a game in which you, along with a band of other criminals go on ridiculous endeavors to go on heists, clear evidence of previous heists and so much more. It has its own simple but very unique and dynamic art style which is not quite retro but in a pixelated look; and dont get me started on the music. This is one of the best factors of this game, with a quirky piano solo in the backround which suddenly escalates as you alert security. The storyline is also exellent as you play the roles of many different characters, each with their own funny personality. As you play through the campain, the story develops and twists and creates great suspence and enjoyment. I fail to get bored of this game with the huge amounts of extra campains adding to the backstory and the almost infinite amount of crazy workshop created levels which you can play with friends. 10/10

Posted: June 11, 2015
												Monaco, What's Yours Is Mine. And Monaco... is mine!A fun and colorful game, with multiple characters with different special abilities to play as.Monaco is a great stealth game, but when you get caught & the alarms go off, it really shines because you're not immediately screwed -- you have options & abilities and the game lets you use them how you like.The thematic elements, the jazzy piano soundtrack, the flexibility-vs-constraints come together for a great game to play.Play with good stereo headphones on -- you'll be able to hear the direction of nearby footsteps of NPCs even if you can't see them on-screen.Play with friends, over voice chat!  just like Ocean's 11 or any team-heist movie you're set up for a good time when working together and using misdirection (or just havoc!) to bail each other out of a FUBAR situation.If you've wanted to star in a heist movie, and you enjoy fun, this game is for you. B-)

Posted: March 12, 2015
												You could almost think of this as a simplified Metal Gear Solid or even its VR Missions. Rather than one massive adventure, you play through dozens of smaller stealth missions. Grab the item(s) needed to complete your objective, then get out alive. It is easy to learn, but not lacking in strategy or challenge; in addition to being stealthy you need to be creative.
